instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan on high immediately. Boots normally.
threads.message: I have a liquid-damaged <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that appears to be working fine except the fan spins up high as soon as it receives power. It doesn't matter what is plugged into it. It boots normally, doesn't really seem obviously slow. I ran the online Apple test and it came back with just a fan error. New fan doesn't change anything. I pulled off the diagnostic connector but other than that I haven't done any repairs. Just ultrasonic. I attached pictures if anyone has any ideas of what could be causing this. Not sure where to go next with it.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan on high immediately. Boots normally.
threads.message:
where was the spill?

also apple online test sucks mayor, its something like a car mechanic that tells you "your engine is broken"

run asd to see what sensor is damaged, high fan is most likly sensor issues

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan on high immediately. Boots normally.
threads.message: thanks, been working on a lot of 2015 boards lately and forgot that 2014 has an ASD. check the pictures for location of the spill.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan on high immediately. Boots normally.
threads.message: Ok, ASD gives me Sensor Group #5 failure. IC2C, IC0R Sensor reading below low point.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan on high immediately. Boots normally.
threads.message:
IC0R will not cause fan issue. Run EFI version of ASD and let it continue on errors so you see all of them.
IC0R is <CHIP>U5400</CHIP>, probably corroded pins on that one for a start.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan on high immediately. Boots normally.
threads.message: Ok, will do. Checked <CHIP>U5400</CHIP>. Nothing at all around <CHIP>U5400</CHIP>. Area looks good and voltages seems good. Same as good board.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan on high immediately. Boots normally.
threads.message: Ran EFI. Only reported fan error. Sensors all came back fine.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan on high immediately. Boots normally.
threads.message: Regular ASD is also now giving only fan errors.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan on high immediately. Boots normally.
threads.message: Bad fan or connector. Or in rare cases the SMC.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan on high immediately. Boots normally.
threads.message: ASD didn't lie. It was <TRANSISTOR>Q6060</TRANSISTOR> so the fan had no rpm control signal. Done. Thanks.
